title: 106_s849
content: The "Youth Substance Abuse Prevention and Treatment Act" establishes grant programs for youth substance abuse prevention and treatment under Title V of the Public Health Service Act. Grants are provided to consortia for this purpose. The Secretary awards grants to eligible consortia to establish school-based substance abuse prevention programs for youth, with priority given to rural areas and Native Americans. Funds are used for identifying at-risk youth, referring them for treatment, and providing prevention programs. The eligible consortium must provide primary prevention programming, target underserved areas like rural areas, and underserved populations such as Native Americans. They must submit an application to the Secretary for a grant and submit annual reports on program activities. An eligible consortium is defined as a group of a local educational agency and community-based substance abuse prevention providers. The eligible consortium, consisting of a local educational agency and community-based substance abuse prevention providers, share equal responsibility in providing services. The term 'local educational agency' is defined as per the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. $15,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2000 through 2004 for carrying out this section. "Grants are provided to treatment facilities under SEC. 582." The Secretary awards grants to treatment facilities providing substance abuse treatment services for individuals under 22 years old, with priority given to rural areas, Native Americans, and underserved populations. Funds must be used for youth substance abuse treatment, including aftercare services. The treatment facility must apply for a grant from the Secretary to provide services after an individual's discharge from a drug treatment center. The facility must submit annual reports on the services provided. $15,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2000 to 2004 for this purpose. "Grants are provided to substance abuse prevention and treatment providers." The Secretary awards grants to State and local substance abuse prevention and treatment providers for training to offer services for youth. Priority is given to areas with high youth substance abuse rates and underserved populations. Providers must submit an application for the grant. Treatment providers receiving grants must submit annual reports on services provided. $2,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2000 to 2004.
